_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pumps, gearboxes, turbines, pipe & valves, vessels, instruments, heaters, etc.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The crude unit consists of two basic processes: thermal fractionation and vacuum fractionation. The Crude Unit is the initial process unit in the refinery. It is designed to take raw crude oil, remove salt and sediment, heat and factionate the crude into finished and intermediate products. The Vacuum Unit is designed to process crude tower bottoms in the vacuum diesel fractionator (VDF) tower and the vacuum tower. Negative pressure, a vacuum, is required to fractionate this heavy material without forming coke.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: New travel zones & emergency evacuation systems.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pumps, gearboxes, turbines, pipes & valves, vessels, instruments, heaters, etc.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such a training personnel and considering safety in design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The purpose of the #1 Reformer is to convert the low octane gasoline feed fractions from the Naphtha HDS and Hydrocracker units into a stabilized high octane blending stock. This is accomplished through the use of catalyst under high temperatures and a hydrogen atmosphere.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: New travel zones & emergency evacuation systems
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Coke drums, pumps, gearboxes, turbines, pipes & valves, vessels, instruments, heater, etc.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will responds to control and contain the release.

The Coker is a thermal cracking unit designed to receive and process vacuum residium from the Crude Unit which is separated into sweet, dry gas, debutanized or depropanized gasoline, coker stove oil, light coker gas oil, heavy coker gas oil and coke.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: New travel zones & emergency evacuation systems.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pumps, gearboxes, turbines, pipes & valves, vessels, instruments, heater, etc.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

Hydrocracking is a combined hydrogenation and catalystic cracking process designed to convert low grade gas oils to high quality gasoline and middle distillate products with a net consumption of hydrogen.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: New travel zones & emergency evacuation system.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pumps, gearboxes, turbines, pipes & valves, vessels, instruments, etc.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The Light Ends Unit #16 is designed to process feed streams containing C5's and lighter hydrocarbons (pentane C5, butane C4, propane C3, ethane C2, and methane C1) and produce pentane, isobutane, normal butane and mixed butane for storage and handling. It also produces fuel gas, Hydrogen Plant feed or LPG feed for Unit #22.

The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The purpose of the #2 Reformer is to convert the low octane gasoline feed fractions from the Naphtha HDS and Hydrocracking units into stabilized high octane blending stock. This is accomplished through the use of catalyst under high temperatures and a hydrogen atmosphere.

The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Unit processes light end absorber release gas and produces fuel gas and propane.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The Tank Farm Unit stores process units' feeds and products. It also contains pipeline receipt and shipping facilities.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: New travel zones & emergency evacuation system.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pumps, gearboxes, turbines, pipes & valves, vessels, instruments, heater, etc.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The Isomerization Unit #45 processes light naphtha streams to remove sulfur and nitrogen contaminates, saturate olefins and benzene, and provides a moderate to high octane gasoline blending component as the final product. The Isomer Unit is fed untreated material from the Crude Unit, cracked stocks from the Coker Unit, and a low sulfur, benzene rich material from the Reformer Unit. The final isomerate product is free of benzene and low in sulfur.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: New travel zones & emergency evacuation system.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pumps, gearboxes, turbines, pipes & valves, vessels, instruments, heaters, etc.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel Unit #26 is designed to process 18,000 BPD of diesel feed and to operate at 850 psig. The design basis provides for a "future case" where the unit can process cracked feedstocks at more severe conditions although numerous modifications will still need to be made to do this. As currently designed, the unit will process straight run diesel feeds from the crude unit. The ULSD process combines hydrogen with the straight run diesel feeds, and processes them in a high pressure reactor filled with specialty catalyst. The reaction produces H2S, which is then separated from the diesel stream and removed from the process through amine scrubbing. The amine/H2S mixture is recycled to the sulfur recovery plant and processed into molten sulfur. The unit is expected to consume 6-7 MMSCFD of 220 psig  hydrogen and is designed to reduce the sulfur in the diesel from 6,800 ppm to less than 15 ppm.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: New travel zones and emergency evacuation systems.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Vessels, piping systems, pressure relief devices, controls, pumps, etc.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The Gasoline Blender (Unit #36) involves blending finished fuels and shipping to the Olympic Pipeline. The Propane/Butane Loading (Unit #37) involves storage and shipment of liquefied petroleum gas by rail and truck.

The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment

is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering

safety in the design, installation, operation, and foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a

release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.



The #3 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit #27 is designed to process 12,300 BPD of light coker gas oil and 14,600 BPD of diesel feed and to operate at 750 psig. As currently designed, the unit will process light coker gas oil feed from the Coker Unit, and straight run diesel feeds from the crude unit and vacuum diesel fractionator. The DHDS process combines hydrogen with the straight run diesel feeds, and processes them in a high pressure reactor filled with specialty catalyst. The reaction produces H2S, which is then separated from the diesel stream and removed

from the process through amine scrubbing. The amine/H2S mixture is recycled to the sulfur recovery plant

and processed into molten sulfur. The unit is expected to consume 12.8 MMSCFD of 1,226 psig hydrogen and is

designed to reduce the sulfur in the diesel from 6,800 ppm to less than 15 ppm.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Whatcom Co. Dep. Of Emergency Serv.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. Non-essential personnel will be evacuated to more remote locations outside the main refinery.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The BP Cherry Point Refinery operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products from crude oil.  The refinery has several regulated flammables: isobutane, butane, pentane, propane, and flammable mixtures.  In addition, the refinery uses aqueous ammonia, which is a regulated toxic substance.  Other toxic substances common to refineries were evaluated; hydrogen sulfide, anhydrous ammonia, sulfur dioxide, and mercaptans do not exceed their respective threshold quantities and therefore are not reported.



Crude/Vacuum Unit



The Crude/Vacuum Unit consists of two processes.  The Crude Unit is the initial process unit in the refinery, and is designed to remove salt and sediment from raw crude oil then heat and fractionate the crude into finished and intermediate products.  The Vacuum Unit is designed to process crude tower bottoms in the vacuum diesel fractionator tower and the vacuum tower.  Negative pressure (i.e., a vacuum) is required to fractionate this heavy material without forming coke.  The Crude Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 74,000 pounds (lbs). 



#1 Reformer/Naphtha HDS Unit



The #1 Reformer/Naphtha Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) Unit c

onsists of two processes.  The purpose of the #1 Reformer/Naphtha HDS Unit is to convert the low-octane gasoline feed fractions from the Naphtha HDS and Hydrocracker units into a stabilized high-octane blending stock.  This is accomplished through the use of catalyst under high temperatures and a hydrogen atmosphere.  The Naphtha HDS Unit is designed to treat the feedstock for the #1 Reformer.  Treatment is necessary to prevent contamination and plugging of the Reformer catalyst.  The #1 Reformer/Naphtha HDS Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 51,000 lbs. 



Coker



The Coker is a thermal cracking unit designed to receive and process vacuum residuum from the Crude Unit, which is separated into a sweet dry gas, debutanized or depropanized gasoline, coker stove oil, light coker gas oil, heavy coker gas oil, and coke.  The Coker is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 33,000 lbs. 



Hydrocracker



The Hydrocracker is a combined hydrogenation and catalytic cracking process designed to convert low-grade gas oils to high-quality gasoline and middle distillate products with a net consumption of hydrogen.  The Hydrocracker is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 116,000 lbs.  The anhydrous ammonia inventory was reduced to less than 10,000 lbs in late 2011 and no longer exceeds the threshold. 



Light Ends Unit



The Light Ends Unit #16 is designed to process feed streams containing C5s and lighter hydrocarbons (pentane C5, butane C4, propane C3, ethane C2, and methane C1) and to produce pentane, isobutane, normal butane, and mixed butane for storage and handling.  It also produces fuel gas, Hydrogen Plant feed, or liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) feed for Unit #22.  The Light Ends Unit is Pr

ogram Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 699,480 lbs.



The LPG Unit #22 processes light end absorber release gas and produces fuel gas and propane.  The LPG Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 22,000 lbs.





#2 Reformer



The purpose of the #2 Reformer is to convert the low-octane gasoline feed fractions from the Naphtha HDS and Hydrocracking units into stabilized high-octane blending stock.  This is accomplished through the use of catalyst under high temperatures and a hydrogen atmosphere.  The #2 Reformer is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 10,000 lbs.



LPG Unit



The LPG Unit #22 processes light end absorber release gas and produces fuel gas and propane.  The LPG Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 22,000 lbs.



The Liquefied Petroleum Gas Unit processes light end absorber release gas and produces fuel gas and propane. The Liquefied Petroleum Gas Unit is Program 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.



Tank Farm



The Tank Farm Unit stores the process units' feed and products.  It also contains pipeline receipt and shipping facilities.  The Tank Farm is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable liquids.  The calculated weight of the flammable liquids stored in this unit is 290,000,000 lbs.



Isomerization Unit



The Isomer Unit #45 processes light naphtha streams to remove sulfur and nitrogen contaminates, saturate olefins, and benzene, and provides a moderate- to high-octane gasoline component as the final product.  The Isomer Unit is fed untreated material from the Crude Unit, cracked stocks from the Coker Unit, and a low-sulfur, benzene-rich material from the Re

former Unit.  The final isomerate product is free of benzene and low in sulfur.  The Isomer Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 1,300,000 lbs.



Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel Unit



The Ultra-Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) Unit #26 is designed to process 18,000 barrels per day of diesel feed and to operate at 850 pounds per square inch gauge.  The design basis provides for a "future case" where the unit can process cracked feedstocks under more severe conditions, although numerous modifications still need to be made to accomplish this.  As currently designed, the unit processes straight-run diesel feeds from the crude unit.  The ULSD process combines hydrogen with straight-run diesel feeds and processes them in a high-pressure reactor filled with specialty catalyst.  The reaction produces hydrogen sulfide, which is then separated from the diesel stream and removed from the process through amine scrubbing.  The amine hydrogen sulfide mixture is recycled to the sulfur recovery plant and processed into molten sulfur.  The unit consumes 6 to 7 million standard cubic feet per day of 220 pounds per square inch gauge hydrogen and is designed to reduce the sulfur in the diesel from 6,800 parts per million (ppm) to less than 15 ppm.  The ULSD Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixture and liquids.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 24,000 lbs.



#3 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit



The #3 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit #27 is designed to process 12,300 BPD of light coker gas oil and 14,600 BPD of diesel feed and to operate at 750 psig. The design basis provides for a "future case" where the unit can process cracked feedstocks under more severe conditions, although numerous modifications still need to be made to accomplish this. As currently designed, the unit will process light coker gas oil feed from the Coker Unit, and str

aight run diesel feeds from the crude unit and vacuum diesel fractionator. The DHDS process combines hydrogen with the straight run diesel feeds, and processes them in a high pressure reactor filled with specialty catalyst. The reaction produces hydrogen sulfide, which is then separated from the diesel stream and removed from the process through amine scrubbing. The amine hydrogen sulfide mixture is recycled to the sulfur recovery plant and processed into molten sulfur. The unit consumes 12.8 million standard cubic feet per day of 1,226 pounds per square inch gauge hydrogen and is designed to reduce the sulfur in the diesel from 6,800 parts per million (ppm) to less than 15 ppm. The #3DHDS Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixture and liquids. The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 169,125 lbs.





Gasoline Blender & LPG Loading



The Gasoline Blender Unit involves blending finished fuels and shipping them to the Olympic pipeline.  The Propane/Butane Loading Unit involves the storage and shipment of LPG by rail and truck.  The Gasoline Blender and Propane/Butane Loading Units are Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable liquids.  The calculated weight of the flammable liquids stored in these units is 7,400,000 lbs.



Utility Plant



The Utility Plant (Unit #30) involves the steam system and other utilities that support other unit operations.  An aqueous ammonia storage vessel was added in 2009 to support the selective catalytic reduction system on Boilers #6 and #7.  The Utility Plant is Program Level 3 because of a regulated toxic substance.  The calculated weight of the ammonia stored in this unit is 17,191 lbs, under the RMP reporting limit.

                                                                                                                                                                                  

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS



The following is a summary of

the general accident prevention program in place at the BP Cherry Point Refinery.  Because processes at the refinery that are subject to the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



BP Cherry Point employees have always been encouraged to be involved in all aspects of operating this facility. Through the years, an open working relationship has developed between employer and employee. This relationship is evident in the employee involvement in many areas, such as the following:



1. Operations and Maintenance Procedures

2. Operations Manuals and Simplified Flow Diagrams

3. Training Programs

4. Process Hazards Analysis

5. Safety Committee

6. Emergency Response Team

7. Turnaround Planning

8. Contractors Safety Council

9. Prestart-up safety review

10. Incident investigation

11. Safety Standards and Policies



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



The BP Cherry Point Refinery maintains a variety of technical documents that help ensure safe facility operation.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Specific departments within the refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining and updating process safety information.



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets.  This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns.  For specific process areas, the refinery has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters.  The refinery ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained p

ersonnel, and protective instrument systems.



The refinery also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes, to ensure that safety features are not compromised.





PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS



The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) performed at Cherry Point will be via either hazard and operability studies (HAZOPs) or What-If Checklist studies.  The HAZOP and What-If Checklist processes are based on the principle that a team approach to hazard analysis will identify more problems than when individuals work separately and combine results.  The PHA team is comprised of individuals with varying backgrounds and expertise brought together to thoroughly review the process hazards through collective brainstorming.



The team's findings are forwarded to local management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation measures is tracked until complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, tracked to completion, and retained.

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the refinery periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted every five years.  The results and findings from these updates are documented a

nd retained.





OPERATING PROCEDURES



The BP Cherry Point Refinery maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Through the management of change process, these procedures are kept current and accurately maintained.  



This information is readily available to operators in the process units and for other personnel to use, as necessary, to perform their job tasks safely.





TRAINING



To complement the written procedures for process operations, the refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in process operation.  



New employees receive basic training in refinery operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with an experienced operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner, they can work independently.  In addition to initial training, all operators periodically receive refresher training to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every three years.  



All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.  A modern, up-to-date, fully programmable computer-driven simulator, with display panels identical to those used in the control room, is also available in the larger units for employees to practice unit operations.  The simulators are fully functional and can duplicate all unit characteristics, and can also be used to simulate proposed changes to determine whether safety parameters could be vi

olated.





CONTRACTORS



The BP Cherry Point Refinery uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the refinery has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow the site safety rules, and (6) inform refinery personnel of any hazards that they encounter during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work.  In addition, the refinery evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the contractor selection process.  Refinery personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



PRE-STARTUP REVIEWS



The BP Cherry Point Refinery conducts a process startup safety review for any new facility or facility modifications that require a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the safety review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment in service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  A safety review involves field verification of the construction and provides quality assurance by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY



The refinery has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems,

relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training inspections and tests.  These inspections and tests are performed to ensure that the equipment functions as intended and is within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified, employees correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service, or a team will review equipment use and determine what actions are necessary to ensure its safe operation.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  The BP Cherry Point Refinery incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs to ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when making repairs.

The mechanical integrity program was developed and documented by the Engineering Authority and is updated by the Engineering Authority, as needed.





SAFE WORK PRACTICES



The BP Cherry Point Refinery has long-standing safe work practices in place to ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these practices include: (1) electronic control of unit entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal

of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (4) a permit and procedure to control "hot work" activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a comprehensive system to manage process changes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures, and other facility changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls will not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training for the change.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION



The refinery promptly and thoroughly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a reoccurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a reoccurrence, and forwards these results to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees who could be affected by t

he findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA re-validations.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS



To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the refinery periodically conducts an audit to determine whether procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  The audit team forwards its findings to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The processes at the refinery have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all program EPA-RMP covered processes at the refinery. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors. In addition to the accident prevention program activities, the refinery has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:



RELEASE DETECTION



Hydrocarbon detectors and hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms.



RELEASE CONTAINMENT/CONTROLS



Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases.



Scrubber to neutralize chemical releases.



Valves to permit isolation of the process.



Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters.



Curbing or diking to contain liquid release.



Redundant equipment and instrumentation.



Relief devices.



RELEASE MITIGATION



Automatic

fire suppression and extinguishing systems.

Deluge system for specific equipment.

Trained emergency response personnel.

Personal protective equipment.

Blast resistant control room.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Cherry Point Refinery has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past 10 years, 1999 through 2008. The frequency of accidental releases has been extremely low. The refinery has not had any release that has gone outside of the refinery boundaries. There have not been any OSHA recordable injuries resulting from a flammable release or a toxic release in the past five years. Every incident is investigated carefully and changes are instituted to prevent such an incident from happening again.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



The BP Cherry Point Refinery has implemented an emergency response program (ERP) to prepare for potential incidents, respond to them effectively, and recover from their impacts.  The goal of the program is to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures, as necessary, to perform their specific emergency response duties. 



The ERP includes a set of potential incidents that are used for emergency drills, including accidental release of toxi

c gases (ammonia), accidental release of flammable materials resulting in a fire and explosion, and accidental spill of hazardous materials on the ground within the refinery perimeter.  



The BP Cherry Point Refinery uses an Emergency Management Organization, known as the Incident Command System (ICS), to respond to and manage incidents.  The ICS has a hierarchical (i.e., chain-of-command) structure that places the highest responsibility on the Emergency Manager, who has the overall responsibility for the emergency.  The Emergency Manager delegates direct command responsibilities to the Incident Commander, who has the highest authority during an emergency.  The Emergency Manger is a liaison between the Incident Commander, the public, and the Company.  The next level of responsibility resides on four section chiefs: Command Chief, Operations Chief, Planning Chief, and Logistics/Finance Chief.  All section chiefs receive directions from the Incident Commander during an emergency.  Each position within the organization has specific assignments and responsibilities, defined in the ERP.  The ICS is expanded or contracted to meet the needs or requirements of an emergency; as the scope and complexity of an emergency expands, so does the ICS.

The overall emergency response program for the BP Cherry Point Refinery is coordinated with the Whatcom County Local Emergency Planning Committee.  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The refinery has emergency response organizations, providing a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to emergency drills that involve the emergency response organizations.



The emergency response program is updated when necessary, based on modifications made to refinery processes or other refinery facilities.
